contentPages.heading: Introduction to Flag Football

lists.text: Flag football is a non-contact version of American football
Games are typically played with 5, 7, or 9 players per team
Instead of tackling, players remove flags from ball carriers
Games are divided into two halves with running clock

image.legend: Standard flag football field dimensions and markings

contentPages.highlightComment: Remember: Player safety is always the number one priority for referees!

contentPages.heading: Referee Equipment & Positioning

lists.text: Whistle - Primary tool for stopping play
Yellow penalty flags for infractions
Official referee uniform with proper identification
Watch or timer for accurate game timing

rows.col2: Overall game control and final decisions
Monitor line of scrimmage and offsides
Monitor sidelines and out of bounds

contentPages.highlightComment: Position yourself to have the best view of the play without interfering!

contentPages.heading: Basic Game Rules

lists.text: Two 20-minute halves with 3-minute halftime
Four downs to advance the ball past midfield
Touchdown = 6 points, Extra point = 1 or 2 points
No contact, blocking, or tackling allowed

contentPages.highlightComment: Consistency in rule enforcement builds trust with players and coaches!

contentPages.heading: Flag Pulling Rules

lists.text: Ball carrier is down when flag is pulled
Flag guarding results in a 10-yard penalty
Inadvertent flag falls require immediate whistle
Flags must be attached to hips, not front or back

image.legend: Proper flag pulling technique - pull from the side, not grabbing jersey

rows.col2: Down at spot of second flag pull
Incomplete pass if ball not caught

contentPages.highlightComment: Watch closely for flag guarding - it's one of the most common violations!

contentPages.heading: Common Penalties - Offense

lists.text: All offensive penalties result in loss of down unless replay is chosen
Explain the penalty clearly to both teams
Mark penalty enforcement spot before moving ball

contentPages.highlightComment: Clear hand signals help everyone understand the call immediately!

contentPages.heading: Common Penalties - Defense

lists.text: Watch for defensive holding on receivers
Protect the quarterback after release
No stripping or batting the ball from runner's hands

contentPages.highlightComment: Pass interference is judgment call - be consistent throughout the game!

contentPages.heading: Hand Signals

lists.text: Touchdown - Arms raised straight up
Incomplete Pass - Arms crossed above head
Timeout - Hands forming 'T' shape
Penalty - Throw flag, then signal type
First Down - Arm pointing forward
Safety - Palms together above head

image.legend: Official NFL Flag referee hand signals reference chart

contentPages.highlightComment: Practice your signals - clear communication prevents confusion!

contentPages.heading: Scoring & Conversions

lists.text: Touchdowns scored by crossing goal line with ball
Offense chooses 1 or 2 point conversion attempt
Defense can return interceptions for 2 points
Confirm score with both teams before restart

contentPages.highlightComment: Always verify the score with the official scorekeeper after each scoring play!

contentPages.heading: Game Management

lists.text: Keep accurate time and announce 2-minute warnings
Communicate clearly with coaches and players
Remain impartial and consistent in all calls
Document any ejections or serious incidents
Conduct pre-game meeting with team captains

image.legend: Pre-game checklist for referees including equipment check and field inspection

contentPages.highlightComment: Good game management prevents problems before they start!

contentPages.heading: Conflict Resolution

lists.text: Stay calm and professional in all situations
Listen to concerns but maintain authority
Explain your decisions clearly and confidently
Eject players only for serious unsportsmanlike conduct
Use warnings effectively to maintain control

contentPages.highlightComment: Your demeanor sets the tone for the entire game - be firm but fair!

contentPages.heading: Post-Game Procedures

lists.text: Ensure proper sportsmanship after game ends
Complete and submit game report within 24 hours
Discuss any issues with fellow referees
Review unusual plays or situations
Self-evaluate performance for continuous improvement

image.legend: Sample game report form to be completed after each match

contentPages.highlightComment: Great referees are always learning and improving their craft!

aboutPage.name: Coach Goddie
aboutPage.description: Passionate flag football coach and referee dedicated to growing the sport in Ghana. With years of experience in youth development and sports administration, I'm committed to providing quality officiating education and resources for the next generation of referees.
